complete confidence in civil servants
particularly Treasury civil servants in
their impartiality their integrity and
their professionalism yes I do I have
complete confidence in them we are
envied the world over for the high
standards of our civil servants and I
would say now more than ever we need to
make sure we attract the best into our
civil service to take him on what is a
an enormous challenge in terms of

Jacob because he is famously courteous
famously thoughtful articulate so I'm
very surprised that he's used that
language I think that they are wrong he
is wrong here and this document that
he's particularly referring to is not a
treasury document anyway
it's prepared across different
departments and it's a tool it's a tool
for informing those of us who on the EU
subcommittee about the choices that are
going to be made it's not about
projecting one way or another so I think
they're wrong can you point to me on the
subject of wrong to a single government
forecast that has been accurate I can
reassure you that we need to have those
forecasts whenever we embark on big
policy decisions the Treasury has them
ahead of the budget we know how they are
they ever write well they are what they
are Andrew they're made of a no-no
sometimes that doesn't mean we shouldn't
have them it doesn't the UK government
has to have forecasts in order to make
certain decisions sometimes they're

degree they're still right about the
directly useful okay
so you don't agree with Steve Baker the

has had an interesting week this week
when he also you know over the whole
debate about what was said when it was
gracious enough to issue an apology we
all use forecasts it doesn't mean we put
all the weight that people might expect

all the time at civil servants of people
to and they've got feelings and some

there's a lot of hurt inside the civil

fact they feel they've been dragged into
the
political argument what again is your

they are important to us we respect
their object objectivity and they are
internationally admired for the system
that we have and we need to make sure
that we continue to attract the best
into the civil service now you say that
these these forecasts are credible if
they're not exactly accurate and we
should remind viewers that in the three
options for leaving the EU that they
their model British growth drops between
8 percent 5 percent and 2 percent in
other words in each case this is a

are tools for helping to inform decision

for leaving the European Union they are
not forecasts for what for certain
consequences of the decision-making
because they can't model for the

to make changes in the country as we go

not going to model the changes to the
future is unknown concerned about those
numbers I'm aware that there are
consequences to certain if you if you
bring down trade if you've set up trade
barriers there is a consequence to your
to a trading nation so I am very
enthusiastic for making sure that we
have as few trade barriers as possible
the Prime Minister has said she wants
frictionless trade at the border that's
what we need to achieve if we put up
trade barriers it won't help our economy
do you think when we leave the EU we
will grow we all contract so we
absolutely grow we have continued to
grow over the past two years and we will
continue to do so what what is important
about the strength and the growth is
good we will grow less than we would
have done had we not it depends on the
actions that we take I mean the wealth
of the country is not made up entirely
from trade it's made out from that's its
culture its rule of law its ambition its
enterprise all these other things which
we need to invest absolutely here all of
that but let me remind you what Philip
Lee the Justice Minister said this week
he said talking about these very same

anywhere near right there will be
serious questions over whether a
government could legitimately lead your
country along a path that the
and rational consideration indicate
would be damaging well I would say two
things to that
the first is it's not the whole picture
these forecasts are tools for decision
making but they don't put in place the
other elements that we hope to in terms
of other trade deals but also in terms
of domestic policy to mitigate it but
the only thing I would say is the
decision to leave the European Union was
not all about the economy we know that
it was about sovereignty as well so for
instance in my constituency in Hastings
we hate the Common Fisheries Policy it
has not been good for the communities we
would like to make sure that the
fishermen all through coastal
communities do get a better deal now
that's not about per capita it's about
communities it's about independence now
the other thing of course about all
these models is they conspicuously did
not include what the Prime Minister
wants which is this generous bespoke
deal that she keeps talking about yeah I
described at the beginning the program
is being a bit like a unicorn yes talked
about but never actually seen have you
seen it well we are having discussions
around what we want out of it the the

leaked document that we were talking
about just sets out consequences of
certain choices in terms of a bespoke
deal she has said what she wants into
what we all want in terms of delivering
that deepen special project about that
yes so what we're talking about is some
kind of Canada like trade deal but with
things attached to it to help us
specifically like a special deal for the
city like a special deal for services
generally well I'm not going to get
drawn I'm afraid too far into those
different sectors we are having those
meetings this week there's been a lot of
criticism out about pre leaking ahead of
those decisions themselves so I'm not
going to and I've been one of the ones
been most critical of that I'm not going
to go into that but what I can say is
that we're all agreed and wanting to
deliver on what we've said which is
frictionless we want to make sure that
the Irish border doesn't get doesn't go
up again particularly significant having
listened to your interview with Gerry
Adams and that we're free to do trade

three things what aim for when when
people like you rightly chastise people
like me for listening to briefings and

go back and read the Lancaster House
speech it's all there so I have done and
I'm going to read you what Theresa May
said about the custard
Union she said whether that means we
must reach a completely new customs
agreement become an associate member of
the customs union in some way or remain
a signatory to some elements of it I
hold no preconceived opinion I have an
open mind on how we do it
is that still policy well she has an
open mind on it we published a document
last year about saying how we would do
it and we proposed either a customs
arrangement or a customs partnership
those are both alternatives that we
could look at but the possibility of a
custard because she is talking there
about the possibility of our customs
union of some kind with the rest of the
EU well I think what she's highlighting
there which we highlighted in the paper
we published last year is that we do not
want to have tariffs at the border so
that is a form of customs agreement
arrangement it is likely to have
something within the customs framework
but I don't want to be drawn to this
whole a or these customs it sounds like
if I may say so you are so intimidated
by the other side of the aisle you
wouldn't actually say the words customs
union I think I've said it rather a lot
already so far and we're not intimidated
I'm not intimidated at all Andrew I'm
happy to reassure you we need to make
sure that we've given a sense of
direction which we have about what we
want to achieve but it'd be wrong to
think that as we enter these
negotiations we can give all the commas
and full stops in the details I keep
reading things that you're I'm terribly
sorry about this but Liam Fox again it's
unmissable he says it's very difficult
to see how being in a customs union is
compatible with having an independent
trade policy and Bernard Jenkin you've
seen in today's papers as well making
something that sounds quite like a
menacing threat if you go too close to a
customs union so that's why I've said
those are the three things we want we
want frictionless trade at the border we
want to make sure there's no border on
the island of Ireland and we want to
make sure that we can do trade deals
outside of the European Union that's the
deal we're looking for that is cake and
and eating it however in the sense that
everybody seems to agree that if we are
in a customs union we can't do those
great big deals around the rest of the
world but if we're not in a customs
union we have the border problem with
Ireland and we have the friction full
trade problem as well well to be fair
you have brought out all the problems
there we know there that that's why
we've said that we want to have a
bespoke agreement now we're not going to
surrender before we've had that battle
we're going to be having those
discussions this week in our committee
cabinet after we've had that you've had
this
today meeting and so forth and Michel
Barnier is coming over this weekend
negotiations are restarting by the end
of this coming week will we have much
clearer idea of what the British
government actually wants me to do well
I take issue with what you say I think
that it's clear what we want to
negotiate we haven't achieved that yet
we've made a lot of progress in
protecting our citizens and setting out
the transition agreement but we need to
make sure that we have this wider
agreement I don't know whether how far
that will go over the next few weeks but
I hope that the government would could
be given the space to try and achieve
that now you mentioned the transition
agreement as Home Secretary can be are
you absolutely clear that it is a red
line that once we have left the EU next
March and we're in this transition
period
EU citizens won't have the same rights
as they have now the critical thing for
EU citizens during the transition period
is that they will be able to come and go
to work here they will need to register
in order to show us that they are here
during that two-year period the Prime
Minister has said that she wants them to
have different settlement rights to the
people who arrived before all the
specified change the red line that well
I'm not going to get drawn on red lines
because these negotiations are only
about to start but she has said that is
what she's seeking in order to make sure
that there's a reasonable distinction
before the specified date can I put it
gently because we've heard both mr.
Bernier and mr. hofstadt said there's no
way that we're going to accept that
we're gonna fold again on me well III
think that you are being too
surrendering too quickly here Andrew
your surrender slowly because no no I
think it's right to have a distinction
between EU citizens who arrived here
before March 2019 and the ones who came
afterwards so I think it's right the
Prime Minister's got to do that there's
a further negotiation to have I'm not
having the negotiation but I support
heart and taking that position and this
being a coup she goes at a red line this
means to be absolutely clear if the EU
won't accept our position on the
transitional rights of EU citizens
coming here as we've just been
describing there will not be a

to EU citizens both before and after the

generous and it takes into account what

well I hope that they'll see it in those

or how we describe them are saying in

numbers you
people people like amber Rudd and Philip

else I have a surprise for the brexit

it's meeting as you rightly say twice
this week is more United than they think
we meet in the committee we meet
privately for discussions I think that
we will arrive at something which suits

looks ahead it's not just about

okay the weirdest suggestion in the

that is such a difficult question on so

now there's been a lot said about where

it's a hundred years since women got the

see it now I think from this government
delivering on the gender pay gap on
making sure that action is taking gates
violence against women and girls is that
there's a big cultural change going on
do you would you like to see the
parading of women at the beginning of

it's going to end with Formula One

the women in sporting events that really

delivering on the Athletics field and
those are the women who I
want to inspire younger women coming up
behind us the the President's Club event
really shocked a lot of people but up
and down the country on High Street or
not High Street behind high streets
there are gentlemen's clubs everywhere
weathers pole dancing and lap dancing
and the same kind of atmosphere pertains
would you like to see that ended in this
country well I think we are reaching a
tipping point now and the President's
Club was objectionable and I think that
women who were working that particularly
on women working anywhere should feel
safe in their working environment what
worries me most is the women working in
the environment some of the ones you're
suggesting there may not feel safe in
that working environment that's what
matters most and I think that women who
are in business who are working they
expect to be in an environment where you
know sexual titillation isn't part of
the offer that's what I think has
changed the forces society of suggested
misogyny should be made a hate crime do
you prove that well we're not going to
move ahead of at the moment but I'm
always going to look at what the Fawcett
Society is suggesting so well I'll keep
a careful eye on their proposals now
there's the gender recognition act
coming up as well are you as
enthusiastic about that as just in
greening was well we're going to be
consulting on the agenda recognition act
seeing how far we need to go with it I
saw today that women's aide are going to
be reviewing their arrangements for
allowing transgender people to work in
women's only spaces I think this is a
very sensitive issue I want you to
consider it very carefully we will be
consulting on seeing a changes we need
to make if any what about transgender
people going into women's prisons for
instance yes again that's something we
need to look at very carefully I want to
make sure that transgender women are
treated with respect and properly and
are always safe at the same time I want
to protect women's safe spaces which is
why it's right that women's they are
reviewing their own arrangements at the
moment and there's maybe we can learn
from them and what would you say to
women including many feminists who look
at what's happened in the women's aid
situation for instance and are alarmed
and worried about the possibility of
people were not yet biologically fully
women being in charge of those I mean I
hear them and I would say let's look and
wait and see what happens with women's
aid let's look at the review that
they're having let's make sure we don't
rush to judgment but above all the
exception within the Equality Act for
only women working
in safe spaces is not going to be
touched
